Award.AwardTitle: Probing Dynamics and Structure of the Nanoparticle Protein Corona to Understand Its Impacts on Environmental Health and Safety

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Link, Stephan
Proposal Number: 1438634
Institution: William Marsh Rice University
Title: Probing Dynamics and Structure of the Nanoparticle Protein Corona to Understand Its Impacts on Environmental Health and Safety

The properties of nanoparticles (NPs) in biological fluids differ from their behavior in water due to the association of different proteins to the NP surface, forming a "protein corona" around the NPs. These proteins bind strongly to the NPs and affect the NPs' interactions with their environment. The goal of this proposal is to quantify the dynamics of proteins binding to NPs and to determine how the proteins may change their structure upon binding. The project will investigate model proteins, as well as proteins in blood plasma. The inclusion of experiments with whole plasma is an attractive feature of this proposed work, as whole plasma reflects the complexity of real-world conditions. The results of this research will be important for the understanding of the fate of nanoparticles, particularly, the bio-accumulation of nanoparticles in the food chain. In addition, understanding the dynamics of protein coating of NPs can be useful for the development of approaches that intentionally coat NPs with proteins in order to prevent other proteins from binding as a strategy to ensure that the NPs do not cause adverse effects on the environment. The PI and Co-PI are both active in outreach to the K-12 community and mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students.

While it is believed that the corona changes over time, as initially the most abundant proteins bind, but are then replaced with proteins that have the largest affinity, very little is known about the time scales of this dynamic exchange among different proteins. The goal of this proposal is to quantify the time-scales of protein-binding to NPs and to determine binding-induced structural changes of the proteins. Correlation spectroscopy will be used to determine the equilibrium protein-NP binding constant and number of bound proteins. The approach will be extended to measure competitive binding among different proteins to the same or possibly different nanoparticles. For protein folding/unfolding on NPs, the PIs will use CD spectroscopy on individual nanoparticles (with the goal of achieving single protein detection levels) and smFRET (single molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer) microscopy of donor-acceptor labeled proteins. The investigators have unique and complementary strong expertise in the proposed area of research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoparticle-based materials are becoming increasingly popular in multiple areas of current technology. This NSF award, titled “Probing Dynamics and Structure of the Nanoparticle Protein Corona to Understand Its Impacts on Environmental Health and Safety,” was funded to investigate the interactions that occur between nanoparticles and proteins. The results of this research illustrate the complex behavior of protein-nanoparticles systems ranging from ultrastable colloidal suspension to protein unfolding triggered aggregation.

 

The response of living systems to nanoparticles is thought to depend on the protein corona, which forms shortly after exposure to physiological fluids. Proteins absorb to the surface of the nanoparticles and their identity and structure determine the biological fate of the nanomaterials. Understanding the role of this protein corona is crucial for the safe and directed application of nanomaterials. A mechanistic understanding of the dynamic interaction between proteins and nanoparticles is, however, often missing mainly due to the inadequacies in current experimental approaches that are carried out on the ensemble level, while strong evidence exists that each nanoparticle corona is different and minor populations can play a significant role.

 

The Landes and Link labs have tackled this issue within this project by applying and developing a variety of novel single molecule and single particle spectroscopic techniques in combination with ensemble level characterization tools. We have been able to identify different interaction pathways between gold nanorods and bovine serum albumin depending on the protein concentration. Overall, we found that local changes in protein concentration influence everything from cancer cell uptake to nanoparticle stability and even protein secondary structure.  In particular, at high protein concentrations a monolayer forms that protects the nanoparticles from aggregation, while at low protein concentrations we found that proteins bind and unfold, leading to nanoparticle aggregation based on strong interactions between unfolded, surface bound bovine serum albumin. Mixing these gold nanorods with low concentration bovine serum albumin first before exposure to cells significantly increased cell uptake. Our results therefore demonstrate the impact the protein corona has on physiological pathways, while the protein corona itself differs depending on the protein concentration.

 

Other major outcomes of this work include the application of fluctuation correlation spectroscopy as an analytical technique to determine the size of nanoparticles and the interaction of proteins with nanoparticles, the advance of super-resolution fluorescence imaging of dye-labeled single proteins to follow protein unfolding, and the development of single particle circular differential scattering to analyze the chiral nature of aggregated nanoparticle-protein complexes. In parallel, we have also investigated the distance dependence of plasmon-exciton coupling to understand how a plasmonic nanostructure will change the emission pattern of single molecule fluorophores, how specifically charged adsorbates modulate the plasmon resonance, and finally how protein binding to polymeric surfaces depends on surface hydrophilicity, surface roughness, and induced oxygen content. While protein coronas form on any type of nanomaterial, we focused on metallic nanoparticles because their surface plasmon resonance provided an important spectroscopic signature to follow both single proteins and single nanoparticles.

 

This award has supported research activities for 8 graduate students who had the opportunity to be involved in collaborative research, present their results at local and national conferences, and publish in peer-reviewed journals. A total of 7 publications that acknowledge this award have resulted from our studies. In addition to the training of graduate students, the Link and Landes labs have participated in outreach activities that include summer research internships of at-risk high school students as well as public lectures emphasizing the impact that modern imaging methods can have on our understanding of nanoscience and on the independence provided by a career in research.
